PM

On the face of it this should feed through into a more risk tolerant market environment. The Nikkei 225, for example, closed the day up 2.8% while Brent crude is currently up 2.54%. However, we are also aware that the Q4 slide in oil prices last year first began to emerge on November 4 and came in the aftermath of a strong signal from Mr Draghi that he was prepared to do more at the next policy meeting of the ECB. In other words, the indications of a monetary policy decision in Europe that would make the USD look (relatively) more attractive also sparked a slide in oil prices. There are no signs of that occurring today but it needs to be watched for.
The split policy board vote echoes closely the split seen in October 2014 when the board voted 5-4 to increase the pace at which it expanded base money to around JPY 80 Trn per year, up from a target of JPY 60-70 Trn; to increase its annual purchases of JGBs by about JPY 30 Trn and to extend the average duration of its holdings to around 10 years. This came on the same day as the government panel overseeing the Government Pension Investment Fund reportedly approved plans for the fund to lower its holdings of JGBs to 35% from 60%, raise its holdings of domestic stocks to 25% (from the current 12%) as well as increase its holdings of foreign stocks to 25% and foreign bond allocation to 15%.

PM

All of Governor Kuroda's statements that he was not thinking of adopting negative interest rates came prior to last week's press conference by Mr Draghi (following the ECB's policy meeting) when the ECB President stated that "downside risks have increased again", that "[markets] should expect interest rates at present or lower levels for an extended period", and that "It will therefore be necessary to review and possibly reconsider our monetary policy stance at our next meeting in early March when the new staff macroeconomic projections become available."
This is reminiscent of last January when the SNB scrapped the minimum exchange rate for EUR/CHF and lowered the interest paid on sight deposits to -0.75bp. This came just days after bank officials had reiterated their commitment to their currency policy and just 24 hours before stories began to emerge indicating the ECB was preparing to introduce QE and its meeting the next week.

11:08 am
PM

Four of the eight members of G8 now have an official negative deposit rate (France, Germany, Italy and Japan). While this does not preclude rate hikes by other members such as the US and UK, it does mean that such a move would likely come at the cost of a sharply strengthening currency. We have already seen the BOE backing away from the idea of raising rates in the near future and a watch and wait statement from the Federal Reserve.
Does this add pressure for a race to the bottom for monetary policy globally?

PM

Now, this came out of leftfield cos Kuroda had only recently appeared to rule it out

PM

On January 15 he stated that he had no plan to ease policy now and absolutely no plan to change the BOJ's 2% inflation target.

On January 18 he said he was not considering lowering the interest paid on excess reserves held at the Bank.

He told parliament on January 21 that he was not thinking about adopting a negative interest rate now. He added: "There are pros and cons of adopting negative interest rates ... The Federal Reserve didn't adopt negative interest rates and yet, its policy succeeded in stimulating the U.S. economy." He noted: "We'll continue to watch carefully how recent market moves could affect Japan's economy and prices."

Speaking in Davos over the weekend he said: "Japan's underlying price trend isn't deteriorating. But some indicators on inflation expectations have been somewhat weak ... We won't hesitate adjusting policy, including easing policy, if necessary to achieve our 2% price target." When asked whether he felt additional monetary easing was necessary at this stage, he said, "We're looking at various data ... and analysing them. I can't say anything more, such as whether we would do anything (next week) or not."

11:10 am
PM

Obv he got back from the Alps and had a rethink

BE

Interesting no-one knew how to trade the news.

BE

As well as the $-Y chart above, the Nikkei (as in the index) was all over the shop.

11:11 am
BE

Have some Deutsche.

BE

Positive aspects:
 Negative interest rates on BoJ’s current account could promote portfolio rebalancing in financial institutions (further increase in lending and securities investment).
 It could depreciate the Japanese yen (or stabilize the yen rate) and have a positive impact on corporate profits. In addition, depreciation of the yen will raise the inflation rate (2.3% rise in the USD/JPY (i.e., decline in the yen) will raise core CPI by around 0.08%).

BE

Negative aspects:
 The move suggests that ¥80trn per year is the maximum pace for monetary base expansion. A negative interest rate policy will reduce the incentive for financial institutions to hold a current account with the BoJ, which we believe will make it even harder for the BoJ to continue its ¥80trn purchasing pace of JGBs.
 The BoJ says that by increasing its JGB purchasing price, it can raise the incentive for financial institutions to sell their JGB holdings and hold current accounts. However, this is uncertain. Moreover, if the BoJ buys JGBs at high prices, it will squeeze its own profits. If it buys at a negative interest rate, that would be a loss for the BoJ. While it reviewed its legal reserve accumulation in November 2015, the BoJ’s finances will inevitably erode. Consequently, we will have to consider the risk of a tapering at some point and a full shift to an interest rate policy.
 Japanese financial institutions have already reduced their lending rates to around 1%, giving them little further downward leeway. Even with a downward shift in the JGB yield curve, the effect on interest rates in the real economy will be limited.

11:11 am
BE

Although a negative interest rate is applied to a part of reserve deposit, it could lower interest rates in financial markets. Therefore, it could hurt profits for financial institutions.
 Kuroda’s flat denial of a negative interest rate policy just before its actual introduction signals a problem on the communication side. In addition, the bank’s abrupt switch in the target back to interest rates, even as it insists on the importance of the monetary base, lacks consistency of policy.

BE

Overall, we believe the negative effects of the negative interest rate policy would outweigh the positive. We see a growing risk that rash policy decisions by the bank could seriously damage its credibility.

PM

(Upaswellasdown -- commenters on FT.com away from AV can sometimes be rather stupid)

11:12 am
PM

And some Barc for good measure

PM

l Upward pressure on USDJPY is likely to continue in the near term in the wake of BoJ negative rates and the ongoing recovery in global risk assets. In the near term, our technical strategist believes the risk is for a move higher in range towards the 122.10 area. A move back below the 118.85 area is needed to suggest scope for resumed downside (see Daily FX Technical Strategy: JPY to extend sell-off, 29 January 2016). Our current USDJPY forecast is 123 by end Q3 2016.

PM

The enhanced “open-endedness” of BoJ policy with indication of potentially deeper negative rates should reduce concerns on the limits of the QQE program, helping to alleviate appreciation pressures on the JPY over the coming weeks. This is timely and reflects the BoJ’s renewed focus on the JPY as the quantitative durability of QQE was coming under question. In this respect negative interest rates will be a sharper tool. Depressed domestic yields should encourage further portfolio rebalancing outflows, putting pressures on the spot JPY and JPY basis. As the BoJ surprise decision comes at a time when speculative positioning (CFTC IMM) has revealed a move to an increasing net long position in JPY, this suggests there is fresh scope to short the JPY anew.

11:13 am
PM

Sell yen hey

PM

Maybe that 145 prediction from Albert will actually come true at some point

PM

However, the implementation of a three-tier system and fact that the policy rate balance subject to negative rates would only turn meaningfully positive from mid-2016 means that the impact on the JPY may not be too significant for long until/unless there is a more aggressive broadening/deepening of negative rates. Moreover, potential further easing by the ECB (and potentially other central banks) into deeper negative rates may make the BoJ’s tiered negative rates a bit more blunt. Uncertainties around Fed rate hikes, fragile global risk dynamics, and extended undervaluation of the JPY also remain significant headwinds for USDJPY and these factors will have to balance against the impact of negative interest rates. At the least it suggests even higher volatility in USDJPY over the coming months as these conflicting forces weigh against each other.

11:19 am
BE

On a standalone basis:
n Imperial offers 10% dividend growth (off a 4.3% CY16E yield), plus reliable earnings (and cash), combined with an attractive valuation. The reason we think the earnings are reliable is that there is little exposure to EM currencies – and it is these that are presenting the main risk to consumer earnings currently.

BE

n The majority of Imperial’s profit comes from geographies where trends are relatively strong at the moment, with performance in the US in particular better than we had expected.

BE

Potential for a bid: We continue to think there is a material, but less than 50%, chance of a bid in the next 12 months. For us the key decision is whether the potential acquirers (including BAT) want greater exposure to Europe and DMs. If BAT’s board believes that EM growth will accelerate again, a bid makes less sense. If it believes that it would be advantageous to get more exposure to Europe (and synergies) then a bid makes sense earlier rather than later, in our view. We estimate it would be mid-teens EPS-accretive.

11:20 am
BE

We've waffled at length previously about the China National Tobacco idea, and won't repeat any of it.

BE

Suffice to say, it's not easy to imagine a Chinese state tobacco monopoly buying a 10% US market share without experiencing a bit of pushback.

Takeover talks between supermarket group J Sainsbury and Home Retail Group, owner of the Argos catalogue business, have stalled over a disagreement on price, according to people close to the matter.

Both companies remain entrenched in their positions, the people said on Friday, with a wide gap between their valuation of shares in Home Retail — just days before the deadline for Sainsbury’s to table a formal offer, write Arash Massoudi and Mark Vandevelde.

One of the people added that the two sides are still in contact and that there may yet be a breakthrough before the 5pm cut-off point on Tuesday.

That would probably be at least 50p short of a valuation Home Retail’s board would be prepared to recommend, traders said.

PM

We initiate coverage on Noble with BUY and a DCF-derived target price of
SG$0.37, implying 33% upside. Noble has lost 75% of its value in the last year
amid the commodity rout. At 0.3x FY16 P/B, the stock is at a quarter of its
average valuation in the last decade. Concerns such as the credit rating
downgrade and accounting issues appear priced in.

PM

33%

PM

upside

11:31 am
PM

Asia’s top commodity trader: Hong Kong-headquartered Noble is a global
diversified commodity trader active in 100 countries. It sources, delivers and
transports energy and metals. Noble owns extensive commodity assets in China,
Brazil and India. In FY16, we expect it to generate over US$96bn in revenue. Richard
Elman is the controlling shareholder and Chairman.
 Distinct pipeline model: Noble’s pipeline model supports the origination,
processing and delivery of commodities. Profit is collected at every point in the
supply chain. Earnings are partly driven by volume growth and efficiency.
 The accounting issues are priced in: Noble has been under attack over allegations of
aggressive accounting, including overstatement of shareholders’ equity, exaggeration
of cash reserves and understatement of debt. We note that PwC has endorsed
Noble’s accounting practices and the company was FCF positive in 3Q15. Also, Noble
has bolstered its cash position with the disposal of its Agriculture business for
US$750m. This disposal was approved by Noble’s shareholders today.
 Valuations 21% below 2008 trough: The stock rose 520% from its 2008 before
losing 75% of its value in the last year. At 0.3x FY16 P/B, Noble is 21% below its
2008 low and offers a clear bargain. Initiate with BUY.

PM

Well, that's a call

PM

33% upside

Credit Suisse has put out its liquidity note again.

BE

About the fifth time I've read it, I think. But it's always welcome.

BE

Here's the key chart.

11:34 am
BE

BE

And the argument.

BE

Higher liquidity a key difference vs 2008: In 2009, both RIO (c$15bn) and
Xstrata (c$4bn) raised equity. While both had high debt levels it was a
combination of short-term maturities and limited headroom that forced their
hands. The headroom for the diversifieds this time round is significantly higher
and, while a rebound in prices appears unlikely, the companies need not
necessarily return to bond or debt markets until 2018+.

11:35 am
BE

GLEN (Outperform): The company’s credit position received significant
attention last year, however, we think the funding position is stronger than the
current share price suggests and once the recently launched refinancing of the
$8.5bn revolver is complete the company will have funding security out to 2018.
If the company achieves its less than $20bn net debt target by end 2016, the shares
should re-rate from a current 13% FCF yield to less than 10%, in our view.

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 87.56, down 2.89 (-3.20%), High: 94.11, Low: 86.00, Volume: 26.21m
BE

Anglo (Neutral): To accurately assess Anglo's liquidity, investors need to ringfence
the SA business, but even outside SA the company has $10bn of liquidity
and does not need to return to debt markets until 2019/20. However, the nearterm
cash-flow outlook is weak and the company needs to execute on the $2bn
targeted divestments in 2016 otherwise net debt will likely climb to increasingly
unsustainable levels.

11:35 am
Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 266.15, down 9.75 (-3.53%), High: 287.85, Low: 262.10, Volume: 5.73m
BE

RIO (Neutral) and BHP (Outperform): Compared with 2008, RIO has moved
from the highest to lowest gearing and debt at BHP has increased significantly
but overall issues are more about cash flows and dividend sustainability (we
model a 50% dividend cut at BHP and RIO may face similar issues in future
years).

Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 1,669, down 31.5 (-1.85%), High: 1,743, Low: 1,652, Volume: 1.85m
11:35 am
BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 661.30, down 18.3 (-2.69%), High: 695.00, Low: 654.00, Volume: 4.14m

PM

The Company wishes to make a corrective statement in respect of the announcement issued on 23 June 2015 in which it stated that Fidelity Venture Capital Limited ("Fidelity Venture") subscribed for 50 million ordinary shares (in their then pre 1000:1 consolidated form) at a price of 0.20 pence per ordinary share for cash.

The announcement did not include the full terms of payment for the issue of the shares which included an immediate payment of £25,000 and further payments to be settled in three parts being one month, two months and three months from the date of the allotment, such payments to be at the lower of (i) £25,000 (ii) the value of 12.5 million Ordinary Shares of PeerTV priced at the average VWAP of the lowest 10 trading days in the preceding month.

PM

In the event, Fidelity Venture failed to provide details of its share trading account for several weeks, during which time there was a significant fall in the market price of the Company's shares. According to the Company's estimates Fidelity Venture has a further liability to the Company under the agreement of about £10,000. However, Fidelity Venture has not made any further payment. Discussions have been held to try to realize some further payment but these have to date been unsuccessful. Consequently, only £25,000 of the £100,000 subscription funds from Fidelity Venture implicit in respect of the 23 June 2015 announcement has so far been received.

PM

Robert Logan Pincock (aged 36) – Chief Executive Officer
Robert Pincock is a graduate of the University of Edinburgh. In his career in the hospitality industry he has
worked in both the United States and the United Kingdom prior to being based in Bangkok, Thailand for
over eleven years. Mr Pincock began his career within his family’s hotel business in the UK, where he assisted
in most areas of operations over a six year period. During this time he undertook a hotel management
internship with the Hampshire Hotels and Resorts group based in Manhattan, New York. After graduating
Mr Pincock had a short stint with Tesco UK before moving to South East Asia. In Bangkok Mr Pincock
began as a General Manager for a new bar and restaurant group and over time was promoted to Operations
Director where he oversaw the group growing to seven Western themed venues. This group was eventually
split between the two main shareholders. Mr Pincock retained his involvement and initiated investments
leading to him and his partners owning and operating four venues. Mr Pincock is well versed with the Asian
culture of doing business as well as with promoting Western brands in the local market.

PM

Thai bar manager

And the chairman is ...

Abd Hadi bin Abd Majid (aged 65) – Non-Executive Chairman
Hadi Majid has, since 2007, been a director and Chairman of VCB, a leading Malaysian investment bank
offering wealth management, corporate finance and a private equity division. In this capacity Mr Majid has
been responsible for growing VCB’s business within Asia. An MBA graduate, Mr Majid has sixteen years of
experience in merchant banking, with roles including General Manger of Capital Markets and Corporate
Banking Department of Bumiputra Merchant Bankers Berhad. Mr Majid’s capital markets experience and
exposure includes reviewing public listing proposals, company take-overs and mergers, underwriting of new
share issues, underwriting for bond issues and investment portfolio of the bank. He has experience in
managing portfolios involved with making direct loans as well as arranging for various forms of structured
fund raisings via syndicated loans, club-deals, married deals, private debt securities namely revolving
underwriting facilities, note issuance facilities, medium term notes and bank guarantees for bond issues.

BE

Yeah, it's a baffling business that seems to have any number of issues both in terms of structure and market.

11:45 am
BE

Yet it keeps hitting the numbers, so no-one seems to care.

BE

Today being a case in point. EPS slightly above consensus.

BE

Here's SocGen.

11:46 am
BE

Revenue growth +5% to £5,718m, adj. EPS 29.9p (+3% beat vs
Bloomberg consensus), including £747m operating profit (+1.5% beat) with engine of
incremental growth remaining UK/Ireland, with Germany/Austria losses of -£34m and Italy
profit +£25m (both slightly worse yoy; investment phase continuing). On KPIs, +337k net
adds for Q2 includes UK/Ireland +205k (highest quarter net adds for 10y) and churn -30bp
yoy to 10.2% (world class). Bear arguments that the net adds are only coming through spin
down lower cost products (e.g. NOW TV) unlikely to gain much traction with ARPU up +1%
yoy to £47. Innovation continuing (including Sky Q launch next month for ultra HD service
and STB recordings able to be played on multiple devices).

BE

Key news for us is the Chairman change, with James Murdoch now Chairman (co-CEO of 21CF and had been CEO of Sky in past) which suggests to us that 21CF more likely a builder not a seller of its 39.1% Sky stake.

BE

Our Buy rating remains based on our view that: 1) with EPL soccer rights locked in to
2018/19 and Sky Europe merger integration on track, the equity story offers low event risk; 2) the Sky Europe synergy target of £200m will likely be raised over the next year as scope
expands to set-top box manufacturing, CRM, and backup transmission centres; every
+£100m of synergies translates to SGe +5% for the shares; 3) Sky’s core business remains
highly attractive: high cash generation, dominant market positions and culture of innovation;
and 4) as we discussed in our 21CF initiation report and the SG Equity Research report M&A Update – A Powerful M&A Wave, published on 1 June 2015, investors should not overlook the bid interest from News Corp in 2010, given its willingness to pay a premium and likely regulatory consent.

11:47 am
BE

And Barclays. Which doesn't even mention the management change.

BE

1H16 results were solid with revenues in line, operating profit and headline EPS
better by 2%. KPIs were largely in line except UK broadband additions, which were
better. After a similar first quarter, this second quarter shows little impact of
stronger competition in the UK and Italy. We leave our forecasts more or less
unchanged. Yes, the market is more competitive in the UK with BT and OTT players
offering new alternatives but Sky has now demonstrated they can still grow nicely
thanks to a superior TV product (6% revenue and 16% EBITA growth in the UK in
H1). Re-iterate Overweight with unchanged 1,140p price target.
1H results slightly ahead – Revenues grew 5.2% at constant FX to £5,718m, in line
with Barclays, and Zone Finance consensus. Operating profit increased 12.0% at
constant FX to £747m, 3% ahead of Barclays, 2% ahead of consensus. Diluted EPS of
29.7p was 2% ahead of Barclays. Interim dividend of 12.6p vs our 12.5p.
Good set of KPIs – In the UK, TV net adds were 146k, vs. our +139k. Broadband net
adds were a strong 144k (we had 98k), with the increase being driven by standalone
customers (+59k vs. our +6k estimate). Churn in the UK was 10.2% vs. our 10.0%. UK
ARPU was £47, in line with the previous quarter and our forecast. In Germany, TV net
adds were 120k, a tad worse than our 125k. Churn was 9.8%, in line with our 9.7%.
Finally, in Italy, TV net adds were 12k, a bit better than our 2k. Churn was very slightly
lower than expected in Italy at 9.9% (we had 10.0%).
Forecasts largely unchanged: We make very small aggregate changes to our
forecasts. These changes result in headline EPS changes of +0.0% in 2016E to 61.8p, -
0.5% in 2017E to 59.5p and +0.9% in 2017E to 69.3p. We are in line with Bloomberg
consensus.

BE

And a bit from Morgan Stanley, which also ignores the management change.

11:49 am
BE

We think consensus forecasts for FY16 will be largely unchanged. We are at EBITA of £1590m (css £1580m) in FY2016 and eps of 62p (+11%). Consensus is at 62p. In terms of mix we think consensus EBITA forecasts for Germany may edge down a bit given the Q1 loss but those for the UK are likely to compensate by edging up.
Subscription based but challenges ahead: The bulk of Sky’s revenues are subscription based. With the UK
economy and consumer robust and with the benefit of UK price increases plus the gradual roll-off of German subscribers from two-year contracts potentially to boost ARPU, we think consensus full-year EPS expectations of c62p (+11%) are likely to be mainly unchanged post these numbers. The market may respond positively to the
impending launch of SkyQ but the Bundesliga auction in Feb/ March is likely to see inflation and Sky losing some rights (it has all pay-TV platforms and slots presently). The Sky Mobile launch some time in 2016 will be a major one, potentially positive for the medium term but with the possibility that start-up costs may be greater than expected. We expect 2016/17 to be a down year of EPS (MS 59p) as Sky absorbs the £632m pa inflation in the EPL costs. Sky does not stand out at 17.2x calendarised 2016e EPS, dropping to 15.8x calendarised in 2017 (FCF yield 6.1% and 6.6%)
